title: Man with breast cancer had to fight for treatment as staff didn't know it was for men
text:

When Beyonce's dad Matthew Knowles revealed he was battling breast cancer it was the first time many men realised they too could suffer with the disease.

The 67-year-old opened up about his fight against cancer, which affects almost 400 men each year in the UK, in a moving interview on Good Morning America.

This month is Breast Cancer Awareness month and the superstar's father wanted to raise awareness that this is a disease that doesn't just affect women.

Beyonce and her sister Solange have now undergone tests to see if they carry the gene that could give them a greater risk of also being diagnosed.

Matthew said: "This is genetics. It also means that my kids have a higher chance, a higher risk – even my grandkids have a higher risk.

(Image: REUTERS/Fred Prouser)

"And they handled it like they should. They went and got the test.”

He first went to the doctor when he spotted dots of blood on his shirts and was given the devastating diagnosis.

Matthew has the BRCA2 gene mutation, which means he had a much higher risk of developing breast cancer.

He had surgery at the end of July and now says he is "doing very well".

Andrew Fowler was one of the hundreds of men diagnosed with breast cancer in Britain when he was told he had the disease in 2000.

(Image: ITV)

The 64-year-old retired banker said: "I just never knew it was possible. And when I talked to my friends and family they never knew either."

And Andrew faced further hurdles in his fight to beat breast cancer as several health professionals also didn't realise men could be diagnosed.

He said: "The first time I went to get [cancer drug] tamoxifen I went to a pharmacist. She said ‘This isn’t for you is it? You can’t have it it hasn’t been approved for men’, which simply wasn’t true.

"Luckily I knew the law but if I hadn’t she wouldn’t have given it to me."

He also had to adapt exercises given to patients because they were all tailored towards women.

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

Andrew said: "I thought it was hilarious because all the literature was aimed at women. After the operation you have to do certain exercises, which are all designed for women, so I had to invent my own.

"It’s funny being a man in a women’s world because women have it tough in a man’s world so often."

The former banker is one of nine brave breast cancer survivors who have taken part in an inspirational photoshoot to show how amazing life after the disease can be.

He said: "The shoot was great, we all had such a laugh and it was wonderful sharing stories. You can’t be maudlin or morbid, you have to be constructive.”

Gina Dannatt world imploded when she was told she had as little as six months to live.

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

She had already endured a double mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy but was told the disease had spread to her lungs.

That was 12 years ago.

Now 61, Gina has outlived her doctor’s expectations and simply chose to live her life to the fullest for as long as she can.

The grandmother from Biggleswade, Bedfordshire, said: "I felt numb when they told me. My arms and my face just went numb and I couldn’t get a. breath properly.

“The end of the world happened to me in that minute. I was scared but I did go home and make my arrangements, I sorted my funeral and even picked a burial plot.

“Then one day I just felt I can’t do this and give in to it. Throw everything away when I’m still here.

“Some people say to me it is because I’m so positive and, yes, I am a positive person but I’m not sure that is correct because I have had dear friends who have been so positive who have not made it. I really don’t know why I’m here. I’m just lucky.

“I get survivors guilt where I’m still here and they’re not it makes me feel bad and I don’t quite understand it all.”

To celebrate the life she has, and the wars her body has gone through, Gina bared all in an innovative campaign by the Pink Ribbon Foundation, where breast cancer survivors stripped off and were decorated by body painter and fine artist Filippo Ioco.

The pictures featured eight women, to represent the one in eight women in the UK who will suffer the disease at some point, and one man, symbolising the one percent that are male.

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

Laura Bailey is just 37 but has been fighting breast cancer for the last two years.

She was diagnosed in 2017 with stage three inflammatory breast cancer that had spread to 11 of her lymph nodes.

She had chemotherapy, radiotherapy and a mastectomy but sadly in 2018 was told it is now in her hip bones. She is now incurable.

The mother-of-three from Sutton, south London, said: “For me I have to keep that fact at the forefront.

"I can’t get into the idea that a miracle might happen, for my mental health anyway. I don’t want to be a fantasist.

“I could pretend and say I’m going to get through this but I would rather be the best mum and wife and person I can be. They say I’ve hopefully got about 10 years.

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

“You know when people say we are all going to die, you could get hit by a bus?

"The difference is you never know that bus is coming. When you’re in my position the bus sounds like a nice option.

“The fact I hug my three-year-old and think I won’t see you finish school, I won’t know your children. That’s the hardest.

“It can feel very hollow, so you just try and stuff as much love and life into it. I love my husband and children. That’s my happy place.”

Laura has a heartbreaking reason for taking part in the photoshoot.

She said: "I want a picture of my body out there that doesn’t make me cry. It was a once in a lifetime opportunity.

"It was like reclaiming myself, being part of something bigger, something symbolic."

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

Fran Haworth, 48, from Surrey, has been cancer free for the last nine years.

She had a double mastectomy and partial hysterectomy in 2010 after discovering she carried the mutated BRCA2 gene despite no family history.

Fran said: “I never thought it would happen to me. If I can tell my story and help one other woman I can feel like I have done something.”

Helen Smith, 55, from Essex, was never diagnosed with breast cancer but inherited the mutated BRCA1 gene and took the same route as Angelina Jolie in choosing a preventative double mastectomy.

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

She said: “It was a no brainer for me. As soon as I knew I had it I was a basket case.

"It felt like you were sitting on a ticking time bomb. Afterwards it was like I could come up for air.”

Instagrammer Kaz Foncette, from London, was just 31 when she was diagnosed with stage two breast cancer two years ago and was diagnosed again in January.

She said: “We were so young, starting our married lives, thinking about travelling or nights out.

"I had no idea it was possible at that age, I didn’t even think to check. I thought it was important to raise awareness and be liberated by doing the shoot.”

Saxophinist Rosemary Quaye, 50, from Cheshire, had a mastectomy after being diagnosed with DCIS and stage one ductal carcinoma.

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

She had an invitation to have a mammogram early at age 49, and nearly turned it down, before changing her mind at the last minute.

Rosemary said: “That scan saved my life. If you have a chance to be checked or suspect anything go for it. I had no lump, no itching, no pain, nothing. You never know.”

Vickie McHugh, 35, from Sutton Coldfield, was diagnosed with breast cancer in August 2017 having being misdiagnosed for almost a year with a cyst caused by breastfeeding.

If it wasn’t for her persistence she might not be here today.

She said: “Even a five minute check can save your life. If something doesn’t feel right keep going back till you feels happy.”

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

(Image: SAM PEARCE/ SUNDAY EXPRESS)

Dancer Samantha Vale, 36 from Chesham, had a double mastectomy after being diagnosed with invasive breast cancer last year.

Heartbreakingly more cancer was discovered in July but she was given the all-clear in January.

She chose not to reconstruct her breasts and wants to raise awareness.

Samantha said: “I want to show people you can be flat and still beautiful. It isn’t an option that is often presented to you, but I want people to know it is there.”

This photoshoot was sponsored by Valspar Paint to celebrate its partnership with the Pink Ribbon Foundation and the Sunday Express, where two exclusive new pink paints have been created to raise money for Breast Cancer charities throughout the UK.

For more information or to make a donation: www.pinkribbonfoundation.org.uk.
description: Andrew Fowler has battled the disease, like Beyonce's dad, Matthew, and has joined eight women in an inspirational photoshoot for Breast Cancer Awareness month
